deliberation: Considered whether the command to eat a scroll is a literal visionary act or figurative. In prophetic literature this is a symbolic action for internalizing God's message, so I treat it as a metaphor rather than purely literal ingestion.

instances.english_text: eat this scroll
ground: taking something inside so it becomes part of oneself and nourishes
posture: God commissioning Ezekiel through a symbolic act of ingestion
instances.explanation: The act of eating a scroll stands metaphorically for taking God's words into himself so that his message will come from within.

deliberation: This continues the scroll-eating scene. Even if understood as a vision, the act functions symbolically as a metaphor for receiving God's word, not as ordinary eating.

instances.hebrew_text: וָאֶפְתַּח אֶת־פִּי וַיַּאֲכִילֵנִי אֵת הַמְּגִלָּה הַזֹּאת
instances.english_text: So I opened my mouth, and I was given this scroll to eat
vehicle: having his mouth opened and being fed a scroll
ground: passively receiving and internalizing something given by another
posture: Ezekiel's obedient acceptance of the divine message
instances.explanation: Being fed a scroll continues the metaphor of God's word as food that must be ingested and internalized.

deliberation: Verse 3 has the filling of the stomach with the scroll (continuing the ingestion metaphor) and an explicit simile comparing its taste to honey. Both are distinct figurative expressions.

instances.hebrew_text: בִּטְנְךָ תַּאֲכֵל וּמֵעֶיךָ תְמַלֵּא אֵת הַמְּגִלָּה הַזֹּאת
instances.english_text: feed your stomach and fill your belly with this scroll
target: complete internalization of God's prophetic message
vehicle: filling stomach and intestines with a scroll
ground: being filled internally by what is taken in so it becomes part of one's inner being
posture: God's insistence that Ezekiel be wholly saturated with the message
instances.explanation: The scroll filling Ezekiel's stomach extends the food metaphor, portraying the prophetic word as something that completely fills and sustains him.

instances.english_text: it tasted as sweet as honey to me
ground: pleasant, delightful sensation when receiving it
posture: positive valuation of God's message despite its hard content
instances.explanation: The scroll's taste is explicitly compared to honey, highlighting the surprising sweetness and delight of God's message to the prophet.

deliberation: Language here is straightforward commissioning: go to Israel and speak God's words. Although 'my words' is anthropomorphic, it is not a distinct figurative image in this verse. No clear metaphor, simile, or idiom beyond standard theological wording.
Identified the phrases 'people of deep lip and heavy tongue' as idiomatic metaphor for obscure language, and 'house of Israel' as a metonymic/synecdochic designation for the nation.

instances.english_text: a people of unintelligible speech and difficult language (lit. 'deep of lip and heavy of tongue')
target: foreign peoples whose language is hard for Ezekiel
ground: speech that is hard to produce or perceive clearly
posture: God emphasizing that Ezekiel's task is not complicated by language barriers
instances.explanation: Describing foreign language as coming from 'deep lips' and a 'heavy tongue' is an idiomatic metaphor for obscure, hard-to-understand speech.

instances.english_text: to the House of Israel
ground: a household standing for all its members/descendants
family/house as representation of a lineage or nation
posture: God addressing Israel as a single covenant household
instances.explanation: The 'House of Israel' uses 'house' as a metonymic/synecdochic term for the entire nation descended from Israel.

deliberation: Again considered 'deep of lip and heavy of tongue' for figurative content; the rest is straightforward. Treated the repeated phrase as a single idiomatic metaphor for obscure language.

instances.hebrew_text: עַמִּים רַבִּים עִמְקֵי שָׂפָה וְכִבְדֵי לָשׁוֹן
instances.english_text: the many peoples of unintelligible speech and difficult language (lit. 'deep of lip and heavy of tongue')
target: various foreign nations with difficult languages
ground: speech perceived as weighty, obscure, and hard to process
posture: God contrasting hypothetical receptive foreigners with resistant Israel
instances.explanation: The imagery of 'deep lips' and 'heavy tongue' is an idiomatic metaphor for languages that are difficult to understand.

deliberation: Identified 'House of Israel' as metonymy again, and the expressions 'hard of forehead' and 'stubborn of heart' as moral/metaphorical uses of bodily imagery for shamelessness and obstinacy.

instances.english_text: the House of Israel
ground: a house standing for all its members
family label representing a whole people
posture: God addressing Israel as a unified but rebellious household
instances.explanation: As in v.5, 'House of Israel' uses 'house' as a metonym/synecdoche for the entire nation.

instances.english_text: the whole House of Israel are brazen of forehead
target: Israel's moral attitude of shameless stubbornness
ground: refusal to be ashamed or to yield to correction
posture: God's negative assessment of Israel's moral hardness
instances.explanation: A hardened forehead is a stock metaphor/idiom for shamelessness and obstinate resistance to rebuke.

instances.english_text: and stubborn of heart are they
target: Israel's inner will and responsiveness to God
posture: divine critique of Israel's inward resistance
instances.explanation: Describing their 'heart' as hard or stiff is a conventional metaphor for inner obstinacy and unresponsiveness.

deliberation: The verse uses bodily imagery of face and forehead hardness to speak of Ezekiel's moral courage and resolve set in opposition to Israel's. Treated the whole parallel expression as a single extended metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: נָתַתִּי אֶת־פָּנֶיךָ חֲזָקִים לְעֻמַּת פְּנֵיהֶם וְאֶת־מִצְחֲךָ חָזָק לְעֻמַּת מִצְחָם
instances.english_text: I will make your face as hard as theirs, and your forehead as brazen as theirs
ground: ability to withstand pressure and not be shamed
posture: God equipping Ezekiel to match and withstand the people's hardness
instances.explanation: A hardened face and forehead metaphorically depict inner determination and shameless boldness in prophetic confrontation.

deliberation: Saw an explicit simile ('like adamant, harder than flint') that extends the forehead metaphor, and the phrase 'rebellious house' as a metonymic label for the people.

instances.english_text: I will make your forehead like adamant, harder than flint
target: Ezekiel's capacity to endure opposition without yielding
ground: being impossible or very difficult to break or wear down
posture: God's promise of extraordinary toughness against resistance
instances.explanation: The simile compares Ezekiel's metaphorical 'forehead' to very hard stone, intensifying the image of his inner toughness.

instances.english_text: for they are a rebellious breed (lit. 'a house of rebellion')
target: Israel as a persistently disobedient people
ground: a household characterized by a dominant trait
posture: God's categorical indictment of Israel's character
instances.explanation: Calling Israel a 'house of rebellion' uses 'house' as a metonym and frames rebellion as their defining family trait.

deliberation: The command to 'take my words into your heart' uses the heart as the seat of understanding and will—a common biblical metaphor. The phrase about the ears is literal.

instances.english_text: receive into your mind (lit. 'take in your heart')
target: Ezekiel's inner acceptance and retention of God's words
ground: the heart as the core seat of thoughts and desires
posture: God requiring not just hearing but deep inward appropriation
instances.explanation: The 'heart' metaphorically represents Ezekiel's inner self, so taking words into the heart means deeply internalizing them.

deliberation: Most wording is straightforward. The concluding phrase 'whether they listen or whether they refrain' is a rhetorical pairing that functions like a merism, covering the whole range of possible responses.

instances.english_text: whether they listen or not (lit. 'whether they listen or whether they refrain')
target: the total range of responses Israel may make to Ezekiel's message
vehicle: two opposed actions: listening vs. refraining
ground: naming both extremes to imply totality
posture: God asserting that Ezekiel's duty is independent of audience response
instances.explanation: The paired verbs 'listen' and 'refrain' form a meristic idiom: however they respond, Ezekiel must still speak.

deliberation: Considered 'spirit lifted me' as either literal wind or figurative divine agency; in context of visionary transport it is personified. Also 'glory of YHWH' is a metonym for God's manifested presence.

instances.english_text: a spirit carried me away
target: Ezekiel's being moved/transported by divine power
vehicle: a 'spirit/wind' lifting and carrying a person
ground: being borne along by a power outside oneself
posture: Ezekiel as passive recipient of overwhelming divine initiative
instances.explanation: The ruach is personified as lifting and carrying Ezekiel, a metaphor for being moved by God's Spirit.

instances.english_text: Blessed is the Presence of GOD (lit. 'the glory of YHWH'), in its place
target: YHWH himself as present in glory
ground: God known through the overwhelming manifestation of his splendor
posture: heavenly praise focusing on God's manifested presence
instances.explanation: 'Glory of YHWH' functions metonymically for God's manifested presence worthy of blessing.

deliberation: Describes sounds of wings and wheels; the phrase 'each one to its sister' is a literal way of saying they touched one another. No clear metaphor, simile, or idiom beyond vivid description.

Detected: (1) the spirit lifting/carrying Ezekiel again as personified divine agency; (2) 'I went in bitterness, in the fury of my spirit' as metaphor for intense emotional agitation using taste and heat; (3) 'the hand of YHWH was strong upon me' as anthropomorphic metaphor for powerful divine influence.

instances.english_text: A spirit seized me and carried me away
target: Ezekiel's being compelled and moved by God's power
vehicle: a spirit physically seizing and transporting someone
ground: loss of self-direction under a stronger force
being borne along by another's power
posture: Ezekiel emphasizing his lack of control under divine impetus
instances.explanation: The ruach is personified as grabbing and carrying Ezekiel, a metaphor for overpowering divine influence.

instances.english_text: I went in bitterness, in the fury of my spirit
target: Ezekiel's inner emotional state about his commission
vehicle: bitterness and heat/fury in the spirit
posture: Ezekiel's conflicted, anguished reaction to his task
instances.explanation: Bitterness (taste) and the heat of wrath depict his emotional pain and anger over his assignment.

instances.english_text: while GOD's hand was strong upon me
target: the intensive pressure and control of God's will on Ezekiel
vehicle: a strong hand pressing upon someone
posture: emphasis on God's overpowering authority over the prophet
instances.explanation: The anthropomorphic 'hand of YHWH' metaphorically expresses the heavy, compelling force of God's control over Ezekiel.

deliberation: Describes Ezekiel's arrival and his sitting stunned for seven days. 'Stunned' is an emotional-cognitive state; the wording itself does not introduce a clear figurative image like a metaphor or simile. I treat the language as essentially literal description.
The phrase 'the word of YHWH came to me' personifies the divine word as an arriving entity, a standard prophetic formula but still a figurative personification/metaphor.

instances.english_text: the word of GOD came to me
target: God's act of revealing a message to Ezekiel
ground: a message being actively delivered and encountered
posture: framing Ezekiel's speech as originating in direct divine initiative
instances.explanation: The 'word' is personified as coming to Ezekiel, expressing the active, initiating nature of divine revelation.

deliberation: The key figurative element is calling Ezekiel a 'watchman' for Israel, a sustained metaphor for his prophetic role as lookout. The 'house of Israel' could also be seen as metonymy, but that figure has already been treated repeatedly; here I focus on the new, central metaphor.

instances.english_text: I appoint you lookout for the House of Israel
vehicle: a lookout/watchman set over a city
ground: vigilant observation and timely warning of danger
responsibility to alert others to approaching threat
posture: God framing Ezekiel's task as protective oversight of the people
instances.explanation: Ezekiel is metaphorically a watchman who must warn the people of coming danger, depicting the prophet's role by analogy with city sentries.

deliberation: The main figurative expression is 'his blood I will require at your hand', which combines 'blood' as metonym for life/guilt and 'from your hand' as idiom for personal responsibility. These form one tightly integrated idiom.

instances.english_text: while from you I will require a reckoning for their blood (lit. 'his blood I will seek from your hand')
target: Ezekiel's culpability for the other's death if he fails to warn
vehicle: seeking someone's blood from another's hand
blood and hand as judicial evidence
ground: blood representing life taken or guilt incurred, the hand representing agency
holding someone accountable for another's death
posture: God warning Ezekiel about severe personal accountability
instances.explanation: The idiom uses 'blood' as a metonym for guilt over a death and 'hand' for agency, to express God's demand for accountability.

deliberation: The notable figurative element is the idiom 'you have saved your own life' (lit. 'delivered your soul'), describing moral-spiritual rescue rather than physical extraction.

instances.english_text: while you will have saved your own life (lit. 'you have delivered your soul')
target: Ezekiel's preservation from guilt and judgment
ground: escape from impending harm or punishment
posture: God assuring Ezekiel that faithfulness frees him from others' guilt
instances.explanation: The idiom of 'delivering the soul' metaphorically portrays moral and judicial safety as a kind of rescue.

deliberation: Found two figurative elements: (1) God 'putting a stumbling block before him' as metaphor for placing circumstances leading to downfall/judgment; (2) the repeated idiom 'his blood I will seek from your hand' as in v.18.

instances.english_text: when I put a stumbling block before them
target: God's causing/testing that leads the formerly righteous to fall under judgment
vehicle: placing an obstacle in someone's path
ground: an obstruction that trips a person and causes a fall
circumstances that lead to sin or ruin
posture: God depicting his judicial dealings in vivid, cautionary terms
instances.explanation: The 'stumbling block' metaphor portrays divinely given circumstances that result in the person's moral and judicial fall.

instances.english_text: while from you I will require a reckoning for their blood (lit. 'his blood I will seek from your hand')
target: Ezekiel's responsibility for failing to warn a righteous person
vehicle: blood and hand as judicial tokens
ground: blood representing culpable loss of life, hand representing action
holding someone answerable for another's death
posture: God heightening the seriousness of the prophet's duty
instances.explanation: As in v.18, 'blood from your hand' is an idiom using metonymy to express liability for another's death.

deliberation: The key figure is again the idiom 'you have saved your own life' (delivered your soul), expressing moral safety as rescue. The rest is conceptually straightforward.

instances.english_text: while you will have saved your own life (lit. 'you have delivered your soul')
target: Ezekiel's avoidance of guilt and judgment
posture: God affirming that faithful warning secures the prophet's own standing
instances.explanation: The idiom presents moral innocence as if Ezekiel had rescued his own life from danger.

deliberation: Again found the anthropomorphic expression 'the hand of YHWH was upon me' as metaphor for strong divine influence. The commands to arise and go are literal.

instances.english_text: Then GOD's hand came upon me there
target: God's powerful influence and control over Ezekiel
ground: being grasped or pressed by a stronger party
posture: emphasizing the divine initiative and authority behind the next revelation
instances.explanation: The 'hand of YHWH' metaphor and anthropomorphism express God's strong, directing influence on the prophet.

deliberation: Here 'the glory of YHWH' again functions as a metonym for God's manifested presence. Ezekiel falling on his face is a literal posture of reverence, so I focus on the 'glory' expression.

instances.english_text: and there stood the Presence of GOD (lit. 'the glory of YHWH stood there')
target: YHWH present to Ezekiel in a theophany
vehicle: manifest splendor as a standing figure
ground: God known and encountered through a radiant manifestation
posture: presenting the vision as an encounter with God's majesty
instances.explanation: The 'glory of YHWH' stands metonymically for God's own manifested presence before Ezekiel.

deliberation: Noted 'a spirit entered into me and set me on my feet' as another personification of the divine spirit as an agent lifting Ezekiel. The instruction to shut himself in his house is literal in form, though symbolically significant.

instances.english_text: And a spirit entered into me and set me upon my feet
target: Ezekiel's empowerment and restoration to readiness by God
vehicle: a spirit entering and standing someone up
personal agent imparting strength and posture
ground: infusion of strength enabling one to stand
posture: portraying Ezekiel as enabled by God rather than by his own strength
instances.explanation: The spirit is personified as entering and physically setting Ezekiel on his feet, a metaphor for divine empowerment.

deliberation: Though the binding with cords may have symbolic significance in context, the verse describes straightforward physical restraint without distinct metaphorical or idiomatic phrasing. I treat it as literal.

Identified (1) 'I will make your tongue cleave to your palate' as idiomatic language for enforced silence and loss of speech; (2) 'house of rebellion' again as metonymic/synecdochic label for the people's character.

instances.english_text: I will make your tongue cleave to your palate, and you shall be dumb
target: Ezekiel's inability to speak unless authorized by God
vehicle: a tongue stuck to the roof of the mouth
posture: God asserting control over when Ezekiel may speak
instances.explanation: The image of the tongue glued to the palate is an idiomatic metaphor for being made speechless by divine action.

instances.english_text: for they are a rebellious breed (lit. 'a house of rebellion')
target: Israel as a persistently rebellious people
ground: a house epitomizing a certain behavior
group identity summed up in one quality
posture: God justifying why prophetic rebuke is withheld for a time
instances.explanation: As earlier, 'house of rebellion' uses 'house' metonymically and frames rebellion as Israel's defining family trait.

deliberation: Detected three figures: (1) 'I will open your mouth' as idiom for enabling speech; (2) the paired 'whoever listens will listen, and whoever refrains will refrain' as a meristic idiom covering all responses; (3) 'rebellious house' again as metonymic label for Israel.

instances.english_text: I will open your mouth
target: God's act of authorizing and enabling Ezekiel to speak
ground: removing an obstruction so words can come out
posture: God asserting sovereign control over the prophet's speech
instances.explanation: The idiom of 'opening the mouth' metaphorically expresses God's enabling and permitting Ezekiel to speak.

instances.english_text: Whoever listens will listen, and whoever does not will not
target: all possible audience responses to Ezekiel's message
vehicle: two contrasted actions: listening vs. refraining
ground: naming both options to imply completeness of possibilities
totalizing through paired extremes (a kind of merism)
posture: underscoring that Ezekiel's duty is independent of outcomes
instances.explanation: The parallel phrases form a meristic idiom: whether people respond or not, Ezekiel must still faithfully deliver the message.

instances.english_text: for they are a rebellious breed (lit. 'a house of rebellion')
target: Israel defined as a rebellious community
ground: house standing for its members and their shared character
posture: God reiterating Israel's entrenched rebelliousness as explanation for mixed response
instances.explanation: Once more 'house of rebellion' uses 'house' metonymically and portrays rebellion as Israel's defining family characteristic.
